content.description: The first 5 bolts are slabby 5.8  then you start up a face. The Beta is very unexpected, probably one of the harder onsights in the Snoqualmie area.  Very well protected.
content.protection: 14 bolts (recommend alpines low or back cleaning some  of the closer bolts)
content.location: Stand on the ledge and the belayer can attach to an anchor. This climb goes straight up with Friesenburg Concertos to the left and Butterfly Realm to the right.

climbs.name: Jennifer
climbs.fa: David Whitelaw, David Wolfe, Leland Windham, Sept. 2005

content.description: For a 5.8 this feels like a startling wake-up call. There are 2 sections that are run out. The first run out between bolts 2 and 3 calls for gear, but can be done without. The second run out is at the top. I guess the last bolt is shared with the 10c? Even with that bolt it’s run out. The climbing up top is easier but would be heady for the 5.8 leader.
content.location: Although this is in the Lizard Ledge section, it's not on the ledge. It's uphill from the ledge at an unstable belay area. Furthest route on the left in this area.

climbs.name: Hummingbird Symphony
climbs.fa: Leland Windham, Brandon and Heather Hren

content.description: Crux is getting off the ground. I would recommend stick clipping the third bolt and just skipping the first two, since the first bolt is pointless. It is a overhanging climb for 3 bolts then delicate slab for 5 bolts. One of my favorite routes at Keechelus ridge.
content.location: About 100 feet below west wall forms a ledge with bolts and routes. This route is at the very start of this ledge. Your belayer should be on the ground. The first bolt is probably 8 feet off the ground in a black overhang.

content.description: Some easy, blocky climbing to start leads up through a cleaner face. Angle up and left through this face, aiming for the faint arete where you'll find the crux moves (and, just out of sight for most the climb, the chain anchors).
content.location:
Start from the belay bolt on Lizard Ledge (about 25 feet in on the ledge). Climb through 3 bolts of easy terrain. From here, the route breaks into 3: a 5.8 (this climb) breaks left toward the faint arete, a 5.11a (

The Last of Summer

) continues straight up the steep face into a shallow corner, and a 5.7 (Butterfly Realm) cuts right to a set of chains just below the yellow lichen.

It would be very easy to hang a TR on

Hummingbird Symphony

when lowering from this route.

content.description: Tricky slab start for first two bolts, then easier slab. You could place gear, but it's not really needed. Clip before a big move over a corner and onto the next face. Easy finish to anchor shared with 5.8 Jennifer on the left.
content.location: 2nd route on the left of the wall. Belay area is on an unstable slope. Route is much further to the left of the actual ledge of Lizard Ledge.

content.description: Some blocky climbing to start leads up to some cleaner slab. Break right at the first possible opportunity, aiming for the chains just below the large face covered in yellow lichen.
